inference:
The interior angle of a regular hexagon is given by the formula $\frac{(n-2) \times 180}{n}$, where n is the number of sides.
For a hexagon, $n=6$.  So, the interior angle is $\frac{(6-2) \times 180}{6} = \frac{4 \times 180}{6} = \frac{720}{6} = 120^{\circ}$.
The interior angles of the square are $90^{\circ}$.
Since the square and hexagon share a common side, the side of the square is a side of the hexagon.
Consider the triangle formed by the vertices of the square and the hexagon.
$\angle A = 120^{\circ}$, $\angle B = 90^{\circ}$.
$\angle ABC = 120^{\circ} - 90^{\circ} = 30^{\circ}$.
$\angle ABC$ is the angle formed by the intersection of the shared side and the adjacent side of the square.
The angle at vertex B is part of a $90^{\circ}$ angle of the square, so $\angle CBF = 90^{\circ}$.  However, this angle is not needed.
The angle formed by adjacent sides of the hexagon is $120^{\circ}$. The angle formed by adjacent sides of the square is $90^{\circ}$.
$\angle ABC$ is formed by a side of the square and a side of the hexagon.
The sides of the square and hexagon share a common side.
The exterior angle of a regular hexagon is $\frac{360}{6} = 60^{\circ}$. The interior angle is $180 - 60 = 120^{\circ}$.
The square has interior angles of $90^{\circ}$.
The exterior angle between the hexagon and the square is formed by the shared side.
By subtracting the angle of the square from the interior angle of the hexagon, we get the angle between the shared side of the square and hexagon, i.e., the angle at vertex B.
$\angle ABC = 120 - 90 = 30^{\circ}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{30}$
ground_truth:
Label the lower right corner of the square point $D$ and the lower left corner $E$. The interior angles of a regular hexagon are 120 degrees and the interior angles of a square are 90 degrees. Thus, $m\angle BDC=m \angle BDE - m\angle CDE=120^\circ - 90^\circ = 30^\circ$. In addition, because the square and regular hexagon share a side and all of their sides have the same length, segments $CD$ and $BD$ have the same length. Thus, triangle $BCD$ is isosceles.

Because the base angles of an isosceles triangle are congruent, $m\angle BCD = m \angle CBD=x$. In addition, because the interior angles of a triangle sum to 180 degrees, we have  \begin{align*}
180^\circ &= m\angle BDC+m\angle BCD + m\angle CBD \\
&=30^\circ + x + x \\
150^\circ &= 2x \\
75^\circ = x
\end{align*} Thus, $m\angle CBD=75^\circ$. Finally, we calculate $m\angle ABC=m\angle ABD- m\angle CBD=120^\circ-75^\circ=\boxed{45}^\circ$.

inference:
The interior angle of a regular hexagon is 120 degrees, and the interior angle of a square is 90 degrees.  The shared side forms an angle between the two shapes.  Subtracting the angle of the square from the interior angle of the hexagon gives the angle between the shared side of the square and the hexagon.  Therefore, $120^\circ - 90^\circ = 30^\circ$.

$\boxed{30}$
ground_truth:
Label the lower right corner of the square point $D$ and the lower left corner $E$. The interior angles of a regular hexagon are 120 degrees and the interior angles of a square are 90 degrees. Thus, $m\angle BDC=m \angle BDE - m\angle CDE=120^\circ - 90^\circ = 30^\circ$. In addition, because the square and regular hexagon share a side and all of their sides have the same length, segments $CD$ and $BD$ have the same length. Thus, triangle $BCD$ is isosceles.

Because the base angles of an isosceles triangle are congruent, $m\angle BCD = m \angle CBD=x$. In addition, because the interior angles of a triangle sum to 180 degrees, we have  \begin{align*}
180^\circ &= m\angle BDC+m\angle BCD + m\angle CBD \\
&=30^\circ + x + x \\
150^\circ &= 2x \\
75^\circ = x
\end{align*} Thus, $m\angle CBD=75^\circ$. Finally, we calculate $m\angle ABC=m\angle ABD- m\angle CBD=120^\circ-75^\circ=\boxed{45}^\circ$.
